patient_information: A 56-year-old male Peruvian with an unremarkable past medical history.
chief_complaint: A 2-week history of fever, jaundice, and confusion.
history_of_present_illness: The patient's daily fever started three months after spending three weeks in a rural area in the highlands of northern Peru. In the second week of the illness, he noticed dark urine and jaundice. A few days before admission, his wife noted the onset of confusion and somnolence.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Three months prior to his illness, the patient had a three-week vacation in a rural area in the highlands of northern Peru at an altitude of 2400 m. While there, he and his wife were bitten at night by tiny mosquitoes and did not use any personal protection. No animal contact was reported.
vitals: On admission, his blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg, pulse was 110 bpm and regular, temperature was 39.2°C (102.6°F), and respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute.
physical_exam: The patient appeared confused and disorientated, with a GCS of 14/15, but had no focal neurological findings or meningeal signs. His skin and conjunctivae were markedly pale, and scleral jaundice was present. The liver was slightly enlarged, but there was no splenomegaly. Cardiovascular and pulmonary examinations were normal.
labs_and_diagnostics: Laboratory results revealed severe anemia (Hemoglobin 6 g/dL) with evidence of hemolysis, including high reticulocytes (8%), elevated LDH (1500 U/L), and hyperbilirubinemia (Total 239 µmol/L, Direct 103 µmol/L). The white blood cell count was elevated at 14.9 x 10^9/L with neutrophilia, and platelets were high at 454 x 10^9/L. The Coomb's test was negative. Creatinine, electrolytes, alkaline phosphatase, and CSF results were all normal. A CT scan of the brain was normal, and an abdominal ultrasound showed hepatomegaly with no focal lesions. Blood films for malaria were negative, but a thin film showed massive red blood cell infestation by pleomorphic cocco-bacillary structures compatible with *B. bacilliformis*. Blood cultures, including those on special media for Bartonella, were negative.
differential_diagnosis: The main differential diagnoses considered were malaria and bartonellosis. *Plasmodium vivax* was a possibility, given the features of severe anemia, jaundice, and impaired consciousness, but this species is not typically associated with severe malaria. Bartonellosis was a strong consideration due to the travel history to the Peruvian highlands where sandfly vectors are present. Less common considerations included rickettsial diseases, leptospirosis, typhoid fever, brucellosis, and viral hepatitis.
management_and_clinical_course: The patient's condition progressed to shock, requiring transfer to the ICU for vasopressor treatment. He was started on a 10-day course of intravenous ciprofloxacin and ceftriaxone. His altered mental status resolved after 3 days of antimicrobial therapy, and his fever subsided after 5 days. By day 4, the bacteria were no longer visible on blood smears. He experienced no further complications and was well at a 3-month follow-up.
final_diagnosis: The diagnosis is acute bartonellosis (Oroya fever) caused by infection with *Bartonella bacilliformis*. This was confirmed by the microscopic finding of massive red blood cell infestation with pleomorphic cocco-bacillary structures on a thin blood smear. The clinical syndrome of prolonged fever, severe hemolytic anemia, and neurologic compromise, along with the specific travel history to an endemic region in the Peruvian Andes, is characteristic of this disease. Malaria was appropriately ruled out by negative blood films.
